studyTexts.title: Introduction to Modal Verbs
studyTexts.content:
[SECTION:What are Modal Verbs?]
Modal verbs are special helping verbs that express ability, possibility, permission, or obligation. They are used before main verbs to modify their meaning.

Common modal verbs include: can, could, may, might, must, shall, should, will, and would.

[SECTION:Key Rules]
Modal verbs follow special grammar rules:
1. They do not change form (no -s, -ed, or -ing)
2. They are always followed by the base form of the main verb
3. Questions are formed by inverting the modal and subject
4. Negatives are formed by adding 'not' after the modal

Example: She can swim. (NOT: She cans swim)

studyTexts.title: Ability and Permission
studyTexts.content:
[SECTION:Expressing Ability]
'Can' and 'could' express ability:
- Can: present ability (I can speak English)
- Could: past ability (I could swim when I was five)
- Could: polite requests (Could you help me?)

[SECTION:Asking Permission]
Use 'can', 'could', or 'may' for permission:
- Can I borrow your pen? (informal)
- Could I use your phone? (polite)
- May I leave early? (formal)

[SECTION:Common Mistakes]
❌ Can you to help me?
✅ Can you help me?

Remember: Modal + base verb (no 'to')

groups.name: Used to vs be used to
Perception verbs: see/hear/feel + obj + bare inf/-ing

items.text: When I was 5 years old, I [blank] swim.
items.explain: When you could do something in the past, use could. Example: I could swim when I was 5.

items.text: She [blank] speak three languages now.
items.explain: When you can do something now, use can. Example: She can speak three languages!

items.text: He [blank] ride a bike without help now.
items.explain: When you can do something now, use can. Example: He can ride a bike!

items.text: (polite) Johnny asks Mom: [blank] I open the window, please?
items.explain: When you ask nicely, say may. Example: May I open the window, please?

items.text: (polite) The kids ask Teacher: [blank] we sit here, please?
items.explain: When you ask nicely, say may. Example: May we sit here, please?

items.text: (polite) Sara asks Teacher: [blank] we use the lab after class, please?
items.explain: When you ask nicely, say may. Example: May we use the lab, please?

items.text: Maybe it [blank] rain later.
items.explain: When you're not sure if something will happen, use might. Example: It might rain later.

items.text: Perhaps he [blank] be at home.
items.explain: When you're not sure if something will happen, use might. Example: He might be at home.

items.text: There is a chance they [blank] arrive early.
items.explain: When you're not sure if something will happen, use might. Example: They might arrive early.

items.text: Tip: You feel sick — you [blank] see a doctor.
items.explain: When you give a helpful tip, use should. Example: You should see a doctor.

items.text: Tip: To finish on time — they [blank] start earlier.
items.explain: When you give a helpful tip, use should. Example: They should start earlier!

items.text: Tip: She's worried about math — she [blank] talk to her teacher.
items.explain: When you give a helpful tip, use should. Example: She should talk to her teacher.

items.text: School rule: Cyclists [blank] wear a helmet.
items.explain: When there's a rule you have to follow, use must. Example: Cyclists must wear a helmet.

items.text: At work I [blank] get up at 6.
items.explain: When you need to do something, use have to. Example: I have to get up at 6.

items.text: School rule: You [blank] show your ID at the gate.
items.explain: When there's a rule you have to follow, use must. Example: You must show your ID.

items.text: It's okay: You [blank] come if you don't want to.
items.explain: When something is okay to skip, use don't have to. Example: You don't have to come.

items.text: It's okay: We [blank] pay now, we can pay later.
items.explain: When something is okay to skip, use don't have to. Example: We don't have to pay now.

items.text: It's okay: He [blank] attend the meeting if he's busy.
items.explain: When something is okay to skip, use doesn't have to. Example: He doesn't have to attend.

items.text: Not allowed: You [blank] smoke here.
items.explain: When something is not allowed, use mustn't. Example: You mustn't smoke here.

items.text: Exam rule: Students [blank] use phones during exams.
items.explain: When something is not allowed, use mustn't. Example: Students mustn't use phones.

items.text: Not allowed: Visitors [blank] park in this area.
items.explain: When something is not allowed, use can't. Example: Visitors can't park here.

items.text: (polite) Tom asks: [blank] you help me, please?
items.explain: When you ask nicely for help, use could. Example: Could you help me, please?

items.text: (offer) Anna says: [blank] I carry that for you?
items.explain: When you offer to help, use can. Example: Can I carry that for you?

items.text: (polite) Dad asks: [blank] you please call me later?
items.explain: When you ask nicely for help, use could. Example: Could you please call me?

items.text: The lights are on — she [blank] be home.
items.explain: When you're very sure about something now, use must. Example: The lights are on—she must be home!

items.text: That [blank] be true, it contradicts the facts.
items.explain: When something is impossible now, use can't. Example: That can't be true!

items.text: It's Sunday — the office [blank] be closed.
items.explain: When you're very sure about something now, use must. Example: The office must be closed!

items.text: He missed the meeting and his watch was at home — he [blank] have forgotten the time.
items.explain: When you're very sure about something that happened, use must have. Example: He must have forgotten!

items.text: Their tickets were for Route 18, but they arrived on Route 27 — they [blank] have taken the wrong bus.
items.explain: When you're very sure about something that happened, use must have. Example: They must have taken the wrong bus!

items.text: Her phone was off all day — she [blank] have seen your message.
items.explain: When something was impossible in the past, use can't have. Example: She can't have seen your message.

items.text: I'd [blank] stay in tonight.
items.explain: When you like one thing more than another, use would rather. Example: I'd rather stay in tonight.

items.text: Would you [blank] have tea or coffee?
items.explain: When you like one thing more than another, use would rather. Example: Would you rather have tea?

items.text: I'd [blank] not talk about it.
items.explain: When you like one thing more than another, use would rather. Example: I'd rather not talk about it.

items.text: When I was little, I [blank] play outside every day.
items.explain: When you talk about an old habit that changed, use used to. Example: I used to play outside.

items.text: She works at 5 am, so she [blank] used to early mornings.
items.explain: When you're familiar with something now, use is used to. Example: She is used to early mornings.

items.text: In 2010, he [blank] live in Manila.
items.explain: When you talk about an old habit that changed, use used to. Example: He used to live in Manila.

items.text: Service: They [blank] the car repaired at the shop.
items.explain: When someone does something for you, use had. Example: They had the car repaired.

items.text: Service: I [blank] my hair cut at the salon yesterday.
items.explain: When someone does something for you, use had. Example: I had my hair cut.

items.text: The teacher [blank] us rewrite the essay.
items.explain: When someone makes you do something, use made. Example: The teacher made us rewrite it.

items.text: Suddenly, I saw him [blank] the door.
items.explain: When you see something happen quickly, use the simple word. Example: I saw him open the door.

items.text: We heard the baby [blank] for a while.
items.explain: When you hear something for a while, add -ing. Example: We heard the baby crying.

items.text: Suddenly, she felt the ground [blank].
items.explain: When you feel something happen quickly, use the simple word. Example: She felt the ground shake.

items.text: She decided [blank] early.
items.explain: Some verbs need to before the next verb. Example: She decided to leave early.

items.text: He promised [blank] me later.
items.explain: Some verbs need to before the next verb. Example: He promised to call me.

items.text: We plan [blank] a new project.
items.explain: Some verbs need to before the next verb. Example: We plan to start a new project.

items.text: I enjoy [blank] books.
items.explain: Some verbs need -ing on the next verb. Example: I enjoy reading books.

items.text: They avoided [blank] late.
items.explain: Some verbs need -ing on the next verb. Example: They avoided arriving late.

items.text: She finished [blank] the report.
items.explain: Some verbs need -ing on the next verb. Example: She finished writing the report.
